climbs.name: Year of the Karen
climbs.fa: FA: Eric Fallecker; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description: 15 moves to stop the pump! Any privileged climber daring to set foot on this climb must wear a double mask and face shield (I don't care how long it's been!). The belayer may have a maximum of 2 feet of slack out at any time. Backclipping will met with the strict verbal reprimand. Those ostracizing friends/family for refusing to climb this will be socially rewarded. Any don't even think of breaking these rules or I will call the rangers, Covidiot! Seriously, the crux cannot last forever. Just one more crimp and this climb can go back 'normal', I promise! Also, that jug over there on the right? You can't use that unless you're an elitist politician, even if both your arms are shot!

climbs.name: Weakened Warrior
climbs.fa: FA: Michael Bratcher; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description: Those without steady work or living #vanlife will find this route way too easy. But if you're a middle-aged adult who once had enough time to climb before you took on all that responsibility, this is the climb for you. It's got some challenging moves but on short enough sections so as not to spit you off due to your sorry excuse for stamina. Seriously, did you really need that second helping last night? And for god's sake, do some cardio! You disgust me!
content.location: Climbs straight through the overhung bulge on the right side of the headwall. Start by traversing out with your feet on the detached flake and then make a slab move to the right-facing crack system.

climbs.name: Wanna Get High
climbs.fa: FA: Steven Hath; EB: Todd Fertig & Eoghan Kyne

content.description: Hey, man... like I got a real dank climb for you to send, man. It like goes so high you can, like, see Apes Wall from the anchors, man. Just have your belayer wear a helmet until it fully cleans, okay man? And don't bogart this all for your group! Send, send, pass. Don't screw up the rhythm!
content.location: From the belay ledge with the tree right next to the wall, this is the right of the two routes. It ventures much higher than the surrounding climbs and has a fixed draw just above the ledge halfway up.

content.description:
Swipe right up some attractive shelves until you can match on the obvious hueco. Then for the ugly face, swipe left. Move through a sustained 3-bolt crux involving shallow holes, a flake, and a throw (some would call desperate) until you get on easier terrain to the anchor. Great for those looking to heel hook up the climb.

Note: Online photos of this climb tend to be more attractive than the climb actually is.
content.protection: 9 bolts with triple mussy hook anchor (middle anchor has a long chain)
content.location: 2 routes right of Crack Horror but left of Cialis Stud (the climb with the two fixed draws). Starts with the series of shelves moving to the right.

content.description:
Simon says you need at least 5 fruits for brekkie.

Simon says that if you don't poop first thing in the morning, you are a slave to your body.

Simon says he can't believe how many people have enough money to buy a Sprinter van.

Simon says he's not a climber but rather a slalom water skier/snowmobiler.

Simon says his favorite team is the Baltimore Ravens because he respects the way they run their operations. Also, he's never lived in Baltimore.

Simon say I should name this route after someone who cares but who really climbs in Malibu Creek anyway.

Begin the same as Malibu's Most Wanted, with the high undercling with no feet under the apron. After clipping the first bolt, follow the bolt path up right to a dish (big enough that you can stand in it) just below the overhang. Then climb the steep bulge to a small shelf midway up the overhang. After a quick shake, continue to the anchors.
content.location: Same start as Malibu's Most Wanted. Just past the trail leading to Toddlers Terrace. Climbs the bulge in the overhang in the middle of the headwall.

climbs.name: Seven Year bItch
climbs.fa: FA: Eoghan Kyne; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description:
Don't get bogged down on this climb. Be the alpha. Make it your bitch.

Historical note: this climb's first 20 feet (as well as Poison Stoke to the left) were once covered in poison oak. Cut down in 2016.
content.location: Starts on the right side of the alcove under the broken flake.

content.description:
Same angle as Luscious but without the deep bucket holds. After clipping the 4th bolt, traverse to the left using the sloper huecos (crux). Save enough for a second crux going from the 5th bolt to the anchor.

Named for the tooth-chipping smack to the face delivered by a popped cam during the cleaning process. Turns out you can find a dentist at 2am if you need to.
content.protection: 5 bolts and double mussy hook chain anchor
content.location: Left of Luscious

climbs.name: Poison Stoke
climbs.fa: FA: Eoghan Kyne; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description: This area of the wall was once the home of a 20 ft tall poison oak tree. Now, it has been scrubbed clean and is just itchin' for you to send it!
content.protection: 10 Bolts, 1 fixed draw at the top & Mussy Hook Anchors
content.location: Starts inside the alcove to the right of Simon Says.

climbs.name: The Phoenix
climbs.fa: FA: Eoghan Kyne; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description:
To clip the chains, you may need wings, or at least a long reach.

This line was formerly covered by a tree that leaned against the wall. The tree burned down in the November 2018 fire. This route rose from its ashes.

climbs.name: Orange Mocha Frappuccino
climbs.fa: FA: Eoghan Kyne; EB: Eoghan Kyne, Bruno Dorn & Todd Fertig

content.description:
The far right side of MtG is so hot right now! No, you're not taking crazy pills, this climb is really, really, really, ridiculously good-looking. But I know what you're saying, "Um, Earth to Brint, it's only 5 bolts." Well, Earth to Meekus, duh, I already knew that! And you're like, "Earth to Brint, you're only saying that. I'm not so sure you did because you were all like 'well I'm sure Mt Project would list the number of bolts' like you DIDN'T know it was a joke!" Either way, get on this climb or are you too cool for school? No excuses like you're bulimic (aka you can read minds), or that you're loco (in which case you can derelicte my balls). Just go send this so you can flash your friends a Blue Steel, Le Tigre, or Magnum from the anchor. Actually, your Magnum is not ready yet. You shouldn't even be talking about it... Oh yeah, the best part of this climb is that you have an option for a Walk Off at the end!

Farthest right route. Climbs the column on the left side cave and crests a bulge at the top.

Sharing the first 4 bolts of Delicious the route heads up easy slab to a big hueco. Then it starts heading right over a bulge to a big hole. Rest here for the crux is next, followed by an easy but exposed finish to chains. Route probably gets its 11a rating for the pure enduro fest required to send. The route sees a lot of sun and can be brutal hot during the summer when shaded areas are more comfortable.
content.protection:
15 bolts to chains

Helmet for belay

60m will barely do it, 50m will not.
content.location: The obviously really long route at Mt. Gorgeous starting at Delicious that heads up, to the right, and out of sight.

content.description:
Don't be hatin'! Now Malibu may not have da street cred of Yosemite, but in deez parts, dis climb is where itz at! Also, grades in Malibu may be a tad easier than Yosemite as well... But don't be hatin'!

Begins the same as Simon Says, on a boulder using an undercling with no feet under the apron. After the first bolt, continue straight up on the left bolt line through the reachy face move crux up to the large hole just before the overhang. Then continue up steep big jugs to the anchors.
content.protection: 13 bolts plus 1 fixed draw and chain mussy hook anchors. The vast majority of clips are on your right side. Rack accordingly.
content.location: Farthest left route up the tall headwall. Just past the trail leading to Toddlers Terrace. Look for a large boulder under the apron for the start. Shares the start of Simon Says but head up straight (Simon Says goes right) towards the fixed draw.

content.description: The route starts out vertical on good pockets and gets slightly overhanging by the last bolt (.10-ish).  The crux comes between the last bolt and the anchor on mostly vertical ground (.11?).
content.location: On the left side of Mount Gorgeous.  Scramble up some 5.0 for about 15 feet to the first bolt, traverse left a bit, and follow up to the anchor.

content.description: Start on a boulder and go up the orange face.  The crux is at the bottom.  It feels like a boulder problem, once you clip the first bolt and top out onto the slabby part its all 5.6ish to the top.  There is a little bulge after the second bolt so you can't see the next bolt or ancors, but once you pull over it you can see them.
content.location: About half way between stumbling blocks and Mt. Gorgeous on the left side as you're heading up.

content.description:
Starts behind the dead tree stump. Climbing above the first set of anchors (45 ft up) is still a bit loose but only like 5.7.

There once was a man named Joe,

To a faraway pocket he'd throw,

But when his hand hit the hold,

His skin did a fold,

And left a bloody flapper for Joe.

Now a man named Johnny can't lead,

And a man named Joe can bleed,

But fear not their fate,

Climb with a clean slate,

For an onsight to this route you need.
content.protection: 9 bolts to first mussy hook anchors. An additional 5 bolts to the top set of mussy hook anchors. (Extension option. Not a 2-pitch climb.)

content.description: More than a mere warm-up for other routes on the wall, Gorgeous offers fun movement on slabby to overhanging pocketed rock. Gorgeous climbs the blunt arete that cleaves the wall of Mt. Gorgeous. From the left side of the slabby buttress, pull pockets to a dished recess at mid-height. Moves from right to left lead up under a steep bulge with an assortment of pockets. Pull through the bulge onto the final slab and double mussyhook anchor.
content.protection: 7 bolts, new mussyhook anchor on the right

climbs.name: Friendzoned
climbs.fa: FA: April "20th" Davidson; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description: Perfect climb to take that special you-know-who up. Good luck with that!
content.location: Left most of the 3 routes just before getting to Mt Gorgeous proper. Climbs up along the edge of the formation. Bolt hangers are brown.

climbs.name: Feel The Bern
climbs.fa: Todd Fertig, James Tolins & Scott Lunsford

content.description:
Fact: the top 1% of climbers can climb over 95% of established routes while the bottom 90% can't even lead 5.11c. This is inherently unfair in a free (climbing) society! No one who climbs 40 hours a week should struggle to send this climb.

The route starts off on some easy jugs up a slab (like climbing with a safety net), but the higher up you get, the more taxing this climb becomes. There are some rests to be found but it's all business to the top. A few long draws will help prevent rope drag.

Note: all bolts manufactured in the US by a for-profit corporation.
content.protection: 11 bolts plus 1 fixed draw halfway up. Double chain/mussy-hook anchor (same anchor as Marauding Monkeys). Long draws on the two bolts over the roof prevents rope drag.
content.location: This left-wing route begins on the sloping rock on the far right side of the base of Mt. Gorgeous. Shares anchors with Marauding Monkeys. There's a double-length fixed draw halfway up.

content.description:
Festivus isn't over until someone redpoints this climb!

Starts just right of the tree stump on the left-facing flake. Climb up to the platform and then up the middle of the flat overhung face. Feel free to air your grievances in the comment section.
Fun route with a very short overhung section.
content.location: Just to the right of Gorgeous.

content.description: Duel your way through a pockety bulge, get a no hamds rest, and then duel your way though a second roof section to the anchors.
content.location: Starts below the bulge just below the tree that is about a foot or two off the cliff. There is a belay ledge (accessed easiest from above) held up by a giant boulder. Climbs the right side of the bulge and veers up and right after the big ledge.

climbs.name: Destination Dirtpipe
climbs.fa: FA: Eoghan Kyne; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description:
While not necessarily a piece a cake, this climb has some tight sequences but will satisfy if you just relax and take it all in. Seriously, this route really packs a lot of shit into it.

Starts just left of the boulder under the apron. Shares the anchor with Feats of Strength.

climbs.name: Dick Pics
climbs.fa: FA: Bryce Islava; EB: Todd Fertig

content.description: Should you send Dick Pics? Sure, 9 out of 10 times you're going to get slapped down. But don't let that deter you. You're strong, confident and have the stamina needed to send this climb. And when your belayer gently lowers you back to the ground, you'll know that they were impressed with what they saw. Hell, they may even reciprocate that send.
content.location: From the belay ledge with the tree right next to the wall, this route is the left of the two that goes to the corner of the roof, then into a crack to the ledge halfway up. It then continues up a short roof to the anchors.

climbs.name: Delicious
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant and John Long, 2001

content.description: One of the best in the park, this route has become very popular.  It begins on the right end of the wall and begins on whitish/tan rock heading up & left up to a large bathtub sized hueco.  From there you go up & out the right side, & power through a steep bulge where you'll find the crux(5.10+)getting to the 7th bolt. The upper 40 feet of this route are on amazing rock and it's only 5.9+.  10 bolts to sport anchors.  Long runners/long draws recommended for bolt #'s 3, 5, 8 & 10.  The pocketed nature of the rock made some bolt placements away from the ideal location.
content.protection: 10 bolts, plus 2 for the top anchors.  The anchors on this popular route are starting to show some signs of wear.
content.location: When you arrive at Mt Gorgeous from the trail, you are on a higher platform of blocks.  You need to descend to the lower area to the South.  A tree leans against the rock to make this easier.  The route starts on the far right side before the hill rises into a jungle. The left line of bolts is Family Jewels. There is a nice tree & a few places to sit here.  Do not be confused by a new route with funky bolts that stick out an alarming amount, which moves off right, after the 4th bolt and goes to separate anchors(chains?)  Delicious climbs pretty much straight up the steep, pocketed wall & overhangs slightly.  Look for the red brown pockets up high, festooned with chalk.

content.description:
Scorpion Crack (FA 2009) re-bolted and reborn on Halloween 2015.

You'll want protection when climbing this dirty little crack horror so a steady line of bolt has your back at the bottom. But unlike your expectations, this crack horror is neither loose nor easy. So don't be like Simon and smack talk this crack horror. Instead treat it with respect and you'll find yourself coming back for more.

Beta tip (just the tip): if you're long enough, you can finish up on this crack horror by enterng in through the backdoor, as opposed to grunting up the arete on the right. The move is a total money shot!
content.protection: 9 bolts, double chain mussy hook anchor

content.description: Well it starts off easy. Big holds, a stable platform but then the doubts start. Maybe it's that first small crimper. Maybe it's absence of jugs. Maybe it's that it's more sustained than it appeared from the ground and you still got that roof up top. Whatever it is, you're going to be tempted to call take and maybe try another climb. But for those who persevere, there is a pleasant surprise awaiting you.
content.protection: 6 bolts and a double chain mussy hook anchor.
content.location: Somewhat blank face with a small roof up top. Just right of Crack Horror.

content.description: Due to you heartless bastards driving your Hummers and burning coal to stay warm in the winter, global temperatures rose an extra degree and caused a wildfire to blow through Malibu Creek in November 2018, burning down the tree that gave the former route, Climb It Change, its name (as you'd climb from sun to shade). Actually, the fire kind of helped out! The absence of the tree opened up a path to the top of the wall, adding 7 bolts and a roof to the former climb.
content.location: First climb when you hike up the hill. Starts just left of the burned out tree stump.

content.description: Start as for Luscious but go right at the top of the slab to clip the first bolt. A fun straight forward climb using pockets and the arete.
content.location: this route starts the same as luscious and goes up the arete.

content.description:
Before the fire in Nov 2018, this climb began near a large dead tree stump. This climb was, hence, the solution to broken wood. After getting it up to the ledge, traverse left until under the fixed draws. From there, grunt and thrust your way through powerful moves. But don't blow your load too early because if you want to perform, this route requires stamina as well.

Warning: Side effects may include pumpy forearms, Elvis legs, girlish screeching, whippers, flappers, sore tendons, scraped knees, wasp encounters, sweaty hands, cramped legs and bruised egos. Please seek immediate medical attention for pumped forearms lasting more than 4 hours.
content.protection: 10 bolts (2 of which are fixed draws), double mussy hook anchor.

content.description:
youtube.com/watch?v=iRS8a8H…

A great climber named Petyr “Littlefinger” Baelish once said: Choss isn't shit. Choss is a ladder. Many who try to climb it fail and never get to try again. The fall breaks them. And some are given a chance to climb, but they refuse. They cling to the ground or the draws or yell take. Illusions. Only the ladder is real. The climb is all there is.

Start on either Malibu's Most Wanted or Simon Says. About 20 feet shy of the overhang a bolt line will appear between the climbs. Follow this up the overhang to its own anchors.

Naming Cred: Andy Feder
content.location: Alternate ending up the overhang to either Malibu's Most Wanted or Simon Says.

content.description: Start as for Cig-arete and at the 3rd bolt move left to finish on the last 2 bolt of Luscious. The crux is the link up but is pretty straight forward moving across good pockets.
content.location: left end of Gorgeous start on Cig-arete end on Luscious

content.description: The logical progression of Camel Straight. Instead of doing Camel Straight, keep traversing and finish on Pow.
content.location: Start on Cigarete and finish on Pow. Follow the logical traverse across the wall.

content.description:
"I ain't paying for those fucking bolts!" said Vicente Fox when he heard this route was going up. The route is Y-UGE! It's the best route in the world. Now some of those Ghetto Wall climbers may try it. But they're not sending their best. Some of them are hangdoggers, some are unsolicited beta sprayers, and well, I'm sure, some of them are good climbers too. And while it may help to have small hands, I guarantee you, this route is big where it counts! And when you get to the anchor, grab it by the mussy! #MakeMtGorgeousGreatAgain

Location: First route as you start up the hill from the base. Merges into Marauding Monkeys at its crux.

(aka "Bengazi Bitch" or "Rush 'n' Reset")

Link up between Build The Wall and Feel The Bern . You get the crux on both climbs. Start on Build The Wall, but instead of merging with Marauding Monkeys, go up and right towards the fixed draw on Feel the Bern, clipping a single bolt before clipping the fixed draw. Finish on Feel the Bern.

Be sure to redpoint this one before it's underwater and uninhabitable.

Starts just left of the tree at the top of the upper tier of Mt Gorgeous. Traverse in from the right up the diagonal ramp. Face moves lead to a roof that has holds just when you need them. Belayer best positioned leaning against the tree.
content.protection: 11 Bolts (2 already have permadraws) to mussyhook anchors.

content.description: This route climbs the pocketed orange and brown face, twenty feet right of K-2. Climb onto a shelf above the base, clip the 1st bolt, and pull pockets over a bulge to more pockets, as the angle eases.
content.location: Twenty feet right of K-2.
